Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Impact of shale gas on renewable energies

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: 1331438 (Suh). This project will examine (1) the effects of rising shale gas production on the deployment of renewable and alternative energy technologies in the short and long run; and (2) the effect of potential policy measures, existing or new, on energy mix change under the presence of shale gas in the U.S. The work will concentrate on interactions between shale gas and alternative energies in the U.S. at both fine temporal and technological scales using engineering estimates and system dynamics (SD) models. This will allow testing a broad range of technology and policy scenarios. This project will produce a potentially transformative methodology for using system dynamics to integrate life-cycle assessment and scenario development for analyzing both the economic and environmental impacts of energy policies. Shale gas is expected to contribute about 50% of total natural gas supply in the U.S. by 2040. The abundance of domestically extracted, affordable fossil fuel can potentially affect deployment of renewable energy technologies in the U.S., which will, in turn, influence the nation's ability to meet other objectives such as reducing GHG emissions from energy. Understanding the interaction between the shale gas and renewable energy technologies in the U.S. energy market is therefore essential in designing appropriate policy interventions that lead to a desirable outcome. The results of the analysis can be used to envision policy options for climate mitigation and renewable energy future under the presence of shale oil. The data and the model to be built can also be used as an input to a parametric LCA model for quantifying environmental impacts of integrated system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thanks to technological breakthroughs – hydraulic fracking and horizontal drilling, shale gas production in the United States has grown dramatically in the past decade. Gross withdrawals from shale gas wells amounted to 33 billion cubic feet per day in 2013, representing 40% of total natural gas production as opposed to 1% in 2000. The shale gas boom has substantially driven down natural gas prices, and is transforming the US energy landscape. The portion of electricity originated from natural gas grew from 16% to 30% from 2000 to 2012. In the meanwhile, the portion of electricity from coal fell from 52% to 37%. However, rising shale gas supplies may cut both ways on emissions. On the one hand, it displaces coal in electricity generation. On the other hand, it may make renewable energy less competitive. In particular, the impact of shale gas on renewable energy in the long run is highly uncertain, when policy targets like the Renewable Porfolio Standards (RFS) are met and room for cost reduction becomes slim.

    We reviewed six studies published between 2010 and 2014 that employed a dozen different models to evaluate the impact of shale gas on renewable energy and the electricity sector at large. We found that the model projections vary substantially (see figure 5). This is even true with respect to electricity generation from natural gas itself, which was estimated to increase by 50 to 2200 TWh y-1 in 2030/35 and by 600 to 2100 TWh y-1 2050 as a result of rising shale gas production.

    Most models projected that the growing contribution of natural gas would come partly at the expense of coal (-100 to -2500 TWh y-1 in 2030/35 and -600 to -750 TWh y-1 in 2050). But a few models projected that coal power plants would experience a slight expansion (30 to 160 TWh y-1) in 2030. Similarly, the impact of rising shale gas production on electricity generation from renewables range from -400 to 150 TWh y-1 in 2030/35 and -50 to -500 TWh y-1 in 2050.

    The model projections also differed with respect to the effectiveness of policy interventions to offset the negative impact that shale gas would have on renewable energy. Some studies show that a cap-and-trade or GHG fees policy would significantly increase electricity generation from renewables even with abundant shale gas supplies, while others show that even more stringent climate policies would not be particularly effective.

    The wide variation in model projections highlights high uncertainty associated with the recent shale gas development and its future impact on renewable energy and the electricity sector at large.
